oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Free Hills Rosenwald School: interior
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Free Hills Rd., East of TN 52, Free Hill, Clay Co., TN

Color photograph of a schoolhouse interior; two rooms with wood floors; closest room has a wood bench on the left; farther room has tables and arched wood chairs; the dividing wall between the room has one column and under the entrance are two floral chairs

Free Hills Rosewald School was built from 1929 to 1930. It was a school for African Americans constructed in part with funding from Julius Rosenwald, a partner in the Sears & Roebuck department store. The Rosenwald Funds were administered by a State board that responded to local requests. The school was located in the rural Free Hill community near Celina, which was established before the Civil War when a slaveholder from North Carolina, Virginia Hill, freed her slaves and provided them with land in a rugged, timbered area of Clay County. Like many other Rosenwald schools, Free Hills represented a new commitment by state and local officials to the education of African Americans, though focused largely on vocational training. Importantly, the school also acted as the primary gathering place for African Americans in Clay County and the surrounding area.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American schools -- Tennessee; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
